Let's make a plan and write the plan in PLAN.md
I would like to create a pure SPA (no SSR, no API even) suitable for hosting on github page (godmar.githubio/jsquiz)
I would like to use React and Material UI
The SPA should provide a 10-question quiz on intermediate JavaScript
(no TypeScript)
It should include the instructions for the necessary github workflow/actions to publish it as github pages.
Because it's hosted on github, it should use a hash router (github doesn't support SPA redirection/fallback)
I'm thinking of using React Router in pure client SPA mode.

# JavaScript Quiz SPA - Implementation Plan

## Overview
Create a pure SPA quiz application for intermediate JavaScript, deployed to GitHub Pages at `godmar.github.io/jsquiz`.

**Tech Stack:**
- Vite (build tool) - modern, fast, recommended over deprecated CRA
- React 18 (plain JavaScript, no TypeScript)
- Material UI 5 (styling)
- React Router 6 with HashRouter (GitHub Pages compatible)

---

## Project Structure

```
jsquiz/
 .github/workflows/deploy.yml   # GitHub Actions deployment
 public/
 src/
    components/
       Quiz/
          Quiz.jsx           # Main quiz container
          StartScreen.jsx    # Welcome + instructions
          Question.jsx       # Single question display
          Results.jsx        # Score + review
       common/
           Header.jsx         # App header
    data/
       questions.js           # 10 quiz questions
    hooks/
       useQuiz.js            ...

Usage notes:

  • If there's already a CLAUDE.md, suggest improvements to it.
  • When you make the initial CLAUDE.md, do not repeat yourself and do not include obvious instructions like "Provide helpful error messages to users", "Write unit tests for all new utilities", "Never include sensitive information (API keys, tokens) in code or commits".
  • Avoid listing every component or file structure that can be easily discovered.
  • Don't include generic development practices.
  • If there are Cursor rules (in .cursor/rules/ or .cursorrules) or Copilot rules (in .github/copilot-instructions.md), make sure to include the important parts.
  • If there is a README.md, make sure to include the important parts.
  • Do not make up information such as "Common Development Tasks", "Tips for Development", "Support and Documentation" unless this is expressly included in other files that you read.
  • Be sure to prefix the file with the following text:
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

Codebase Exploration Report for jsquiz

1. Project Type & Framework

Perfect! Now I have a comprehensive understanding of the project. Let me create a summary report:

Codebase Exploration Report for jsquiz

1. Project Type & Framework

This is a React Router 7 full-stack web application with the following characteristics:

  • Framework: React Router v7.12.0 (modern, production-ready framework)
  • Language: TypeScript (strict mode enabled)
  • Template: Official React Router template
  • Architecture: Server-side rendering (SSR) enabled by default, with built-in full-stack capabilities
  • UI Framework: React 19.2.4 with React DOM
  • Styling: TailwindCSS v4.1.13

2. Build System & Key Commands

All commands are defined in /home/gback/cs3754/jsquiz/package.json:

Command Purpose
npm run dev Start development server with HMR (Hot Module Replacement) at http://localhost:5173
npm run build Create optimized production build
npm run start Start production server from built assets
npm run typecheck Generate React Router types and run TypeScript compiler

Build System:

  • Build Tool: Vite 7.1.7 (configured in /home/gback/cs3754/jsquiz/vite.config.ts)
  • Bundler: React Router build system (uses @react-router/dev)
  • Output: Built artifacts in /build directory with separate /build/client and /build/server directories

3. High-Level Architecture & Directory Structure

jsquiz/
 app/                          # Application source code
    root.tsx                  # Root layout component with error boundary
    routes.ts                 # Route configuration (React Router v7 file-based routing)
    routes/
       home.tsx              # Home page component
    welcome/
       welcome.tsx           # Welcome component (template starter page)
       logo-dark.svg         # Dark theme logo
       logo-light.svg        # Light theme logo
    app.css                   # Global app styles (TailwindCSS imports)

 public/                       # Static assets
    favicon.ico               # Favicon

 build/                        # Generated build output (git-ignored)
    client/                   # Client-side static assets
    server/                   # Server-side code

 Configuration Files:
    package.json              # Dependencies and scripts
    package-lock.json         # Locked versions
    tsconfig.json             # TypeScript configuration
    vite.config.ts            # Vite build configuration
    react-router.config.ts    # React Router configuration (SSR enabled)
    Dockerfile                # Multi-stage Docker build
    .gitignore                # Git ignore patterns
    .dockerignore             # Docker ignore patterns
    README.md                 # Project documentation

 .git/                         # Git repository

4. Key Architecture Patterns

React Router v7 Features:

  • Type-safe routes: Generated types in .react-router/types/ directory
  • File-based routing: Routes defined via routes.ts configuration
  • Server-side rendering: Enabled by default in react-router.config.ts
  • Automatic type generation: Running npm run typecheck generates types for each route
  • Error boundaries: Root layout includes custom error handling and 404 pages

TypeScript Configuration (tsconfig.json):

  • Target: ES2022
  • Strict mode enabled
  • Path alias: ~/* maps to ./app/*
  • Includes JSX (react-jsx factory)
  • Module resolution: bundler

Build Pipeline:

  • Vite plugins: tailwindcss, reactRouter, tsconfigPaths
  • Separate client and server bundles for SSR
  • TailwindCSS v4 with Vite integration

5. Existing Configuration Files

Present:

  • README.md (/home/gback/cs3754/jsquiz/README.md) - Complete with getting started guide
  • package.json - Defines all scripts and dependencies
  • tsconfig.json - TypeScript configuration
  • vite.config.ts - Vite bundler configuration
  • react-router.config.ts - Framework configuration
  • Dockerfile - Multi-stage Docker build

Not Present:

  • CLAUDE.md - No Claude Code instructions file
  • .cursorrules - No Cursor IDE rules
  • .cursor/rules/ - No Cursor directory
  • .github/copilot-instructions.md - No GitHub Copilot instructions
  • .github/ directory - No GitHub workflows or templates

6. Development Environment Notes

Node/Dependencies:

  • Node.js: v20 (from Dockerfile)
  • Package manager: npm (package-lock.json present)
  • Install command: npm install

Key Dependencies:

  • React Router (main framework)
  • Tailwind CSS (styling)
  • TailwindCSS Vite plugin (Tailwind integration)
  • isbot (user agent detection for SSR)

Git Status:

  • Clean working directory
  • Initial commit from create-react-router template

Summary for New Developers

This is a React Router v7 full-stack application using:

  1. TypeScript for type safety
  2. Vite for fast development and bundling
  3. TailwindCSS for styling
  4. Server-side rendering enabled by default

To get started:

  • Run npm install to install dependencies
  • Run npm run dev to start the development server (localhost:5173)
  • Edit components in /app (e.g., /app/routes/home.tsx)
  • The route configuration is in /app/routes.ts
  • Global styles are in /app/app.css (TailwindCSS)
  • Run npm run build to create a production build

The project follows React Router v7's conventions and is production-ready with Docker support.

# Welcome to React Router!

A modern, production-ready template for building full-stack React applications using React Router.

[![Open in StackBlitz](https://developer.stackblitz.com/img/open_in_stackblitz.svg)](https://stackblitz.com/github/remix-run/react-router-templates/tree/main/default)

# Welcome to React Router!

A modern, production-ready template for building full-stack React applications using React Router.

[![Open in StackBlitz](https://developer.stackblitz.com/img/open_in_stackblitz.svg)](https://stackblitz.com/github/remix-run/react-router-templates/tree/main/default)

## Features

-  Server-side rendering
-  Hot Module Replacement (HMR)
-  Asset bundling and optimization
-  Data loading and mutations
-  TypeScript by default
-  TailwindCSS for styling
-  [React Router docs](https://reactrouter.com/)

## Getting Started

### Installation

Install the dependencies:

```bash
npm install
```

### Development

Start the development server with HMR:

```bash
npm run dev
```

Your application will be available at `http://localhost:5173`.

## Building for Production

Create a production build:

```bash
npm run build
```

## Deployment

### Docker Deployment

To build and run using Docker:

```bash
docker build -t my-app .

# Run the container
docker run -p 3000:3000 my-app
```

The containerized application can be deployed to any platform that supports Docker, including:

- AWS ECS
- Google Cloud Run
- Azure Container Apps
- Digital Ocean App Platform
- Fly.io
- Railway

### DIY Deployment

If you're familiar with deploying Node applications, the built-in app server is production-ready.

Make sure to deploy the output of `npm run build`

```
 package.json
 package-lock.json (or pnpm-lock.yaml, or bun.lockb)
 build/
    client/    # Static assets
    server/    # Server-side code
```

## Styling

This template comes with [Tailwind CSS](https://tailwindcss.com/) already configured for a simple default starting experience. You can use whatever CSS framework you prefer.

---

Built with  using React Router.

But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.

import {
  isRouteErrorResponse,
  Links,
  Meta,
  Outlet,
  Scripts,
  ScrollRestoration,
} from "react-router";

import type { Route } from "./+types/root";
import "./app.css";

export const links: Route.LinksFunction = () => [
  { rel: "preconnect", href: "https://fonts.googleapis.com" },
  {
    rel: "preconnect",
    href: "https://fonts.gstatic.com",
    crossOrigin: "anonymous",
  },
  {
    rel: "stylesheet",
    href: "https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Inter:ital,opsz,wght@0,14..32,100..900;1,14..32,100..900&display=swap",
  },
];

export function Layout({ children }: { children: React.ReactNode }) {
  return (
    <html lang="en">
      <head>
        <meta charSet="utf-8" />
        <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1" />
        <Meta />
        <Links />
      </head>
      <body>
        {children}
        <ScrollRestoration />
        <Scripts />
      </body>
    </html>
  );
}

export default function App() {
  return <Outlet />;
}

export function ErrorBoundary({ error }: Route.ErrorBoundaryProps) {
  let message = "Oops!";
  let details = "An unexpected error occurred.";
  let stack: string | undefined;

  if (isRouteErrorResponse(error)) {
    message = error.status === 404 ? "404" : "Error";
    details =
      error.status === 404
        ? "The requested page could not be found."
        : error.statusText || details;
  } else if (import.meta.env.DEV && error && error instanceof Error) {
    details = error.message;
    stack = error.stack;
  }

  return (
    <main className="pt-16 p-4 container mx-auto">
      <h1>{message}</h1>
      <p>{details}</p>
      {stack && (
        <pre className="w-full p-4 overflow-x-auto">
          <code>{stack}</code>
        </pre>
      )}
    </main>
  );
}
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.

      "~/*": ["./app/*"]
    },

## Commands

# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Commands

- `npm run dev` - Start development server with HMR at http://localhost:5173
- `npm run build` - Create production build
- `npm run start` - Start production server
- `npm run typecheck` - Generate React Router types and run TypeScript compiler

## Architecture

This is a React Router v7 full-stack application with server-side rendering enabled.

**Key Technologies:**
- React Router v7 (framework)
- React 19
- TypeScript (strict mode)
- TailwindCSS v4
- Vite (build tool)

**Project Structure:**
- `app/` - Application source code
  - `root.tsx` - Root layout with error boundary
  - `routes.ts` - Route configuration
  - `routes/` - Route components
  - `app.css` - Global styles (TailwindCSS)
- `build/` - Generated build output (client/ and server/ bundles)
- `public/` - Static assets

**React Router v7 Conventions:**
- Routes are defined in `app/routes.ts` using the `RouteConfig` type
- Type-safe routes are generated in `.react-router/types/` (run `npm run typecheck` to generate)
- Route types are imported as `import type { Route } from "./+types/[route-name]"`
- Path alias `~/*` maps to `./app/*`
2026-01-27 04:55:46 
File created successfully at: /home/gback/cs3754/jsquiz/CLAUDE.md ...
Assistant
2026-01-27 04:55:50
Input: 1 | Output: 1 | Cache Creation: 495 | Cache Read: 23039

I've created the CLAUDE.md file with the essential information for working with this React Router v7 codebase. The file includes:

  1. Commands - The key npm scripts for development, building, and type checking
  2. Architecture - Key technologies and project structure overview
  3. React Router v7 Conventions - The framework-specific patterns that are important to understand (route configuration, type generation, path aliases)

The file is concise and focuses on what's unique to this project rather than generic development practices. It avoids listing every file since the structure is discoverable, and focuses on the "big picture" patterns that require understanding the framework.

User
2026-01-27 04:56:17 
I'd like to build an SPA, with no SSR and no API, suitable for deployment on github page (github.io).
2 thoughts
6 tools, 2 thoughts total
Thinking
2026-01-27 04:56:22
Input: 10 | Output: 5 | Cache Creation: 6103 | Cache Read: 17778

The user wants to convert this React Router v7 app from an SSR full-stack application to a client-side only SPA (Single Page Application) that can be deployed on GitHub Pages. This means:

  1. Disable SSR - React Router v7 has a configuration option for this
  2. Configure for static file output - GitHub Pages serves static files
  3. Handle client-side routing for GitHub Pages (which doesn't have server-side routing)

Let me check the react-router.config.ts to see the current configuration and understand what needs to change.

3 tools

2026-01-27 04:56:22
2026-01-27 04:56:23 
1
2
3
4
5
6
7
import type { Config } from "@react-router/dev/config";

export default {
  // Config options...
  // Server-side render by default, to enable SPA mode set this to `false`
  ssr: true,
} satisfies Config;

But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.

import { reactRouter } from "@react-router/dev/vite";
import tailwindcss from "@tailwindcss/vite";
import { defineConfig } from "vite";
import tsconfigPaths from "vite-tsconfig-paths";

export default defineConfig({
  plugins: [tailwindcss(), reactRouter(), tsconfigPaths()],
});

{
  "name": "jsquiz",
  "private": true,
  "type": "module",
  "scripts": {
    "build": "react-router build",
    "dev": "react-router dev",
    "start": "react-router-serve ./build/server/index.js",
    "typecheck": "react-router typegen && tsc"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "@react-router/node": "7.12.0",
    "@react-router/serve": "7.12.0",
    "isbot": "^5.1.31",
    "react": "^19.2.4",
    "react-dom": "^19.2.4",

  }
}
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.

2026-01-27 04:56:28
Input: 8 | Output: 1 | Cache Creation: 1384 | Cache Read: 23881

Now I understand the current setup. To convert this to a static SPA for GitHub Pages, I need to:

  1. Set ssr: false in react-router.config.ts
  2. Configure the base path in vite.config.ts (for GitHub Pages, if deploying to a project page like username.github.io/repo-name, need to set base to /repo-name/)
  3. Remove server-side dependencies that won't be needed (@react-router/node, @react-router/serve, isbot)
  4. Update the start script since there's no server to run
  5. For GitHub Pages with client-side routing, we need to handle the 404 fallback - typically by copying index.html to 404.html

Let me make these changes.

# Plan: Convert to Static SPA for GitHub Pages

## Goal
Convert the React Router v7 app from SSR to a client-only SPA deployable on GitHub Pages (username.github.io/jsquiz).

# Plan: Convert to Static SPA for GitHub Pages

## Goal
Convert the React Router v7 app from SSR to a client-only SPA deployable on GitHub Pages (username.github.io/jsquiz).

## Changes Required

### 1. Disable SSR (`react-router.config.ts`)
- Set `ssr: false`
- Add `basename: "/jsquiz/"` for GitHub Pages project path

### 2. Configure Vite base path (`vite.config.ts`)
- Add `base: "/jsquiz/"` for correct asset URLs on GitHub Pages

### 3. Update package.json
- Remove server dependencies: `@react-router/node`, `@react-router/serve`, `isbot`
- Remove `start` script (no server needed)
- Update `build` script to copy `index.html` to `404.html` (handles client-side routing on GitHub Pages)
- Add `preview` script for local testing of production build

### 4. Delete Dockerfile (optional)
- No longer needed for static site deployment

## Files to Modify
- `react-router.config.ts`
- `vite.config.ts`
- `package.json`

## Files to Delete (optional)
- `Dockerfile`
- `.dockerignore`

## Verification
1. Run `npm install` to update dependencies
2. Run `npm run dev` to verify dev server works
3. Run `npm run build` to create static build
4. Run `npm run preview` to test production build locally
5. Verify `build/client/` contains static files including `404.html`

Plan: Convert to Static SPA for GitHub Pages

Goal

Convert the React Router v7 app from SSR to a client-only SPA deployable on GitHub Pages (username.github.io/jsquiz).

Changes Required

1. Disable SSR (react-router.config.ts)

  • Set ssr: false
  • Add basename: "/jsquiz/" for GitHub Pages project path

2. Configure Vite base path (vite.config.ts)

  • Add base: "/jsquiz/" for correct asset URLs on GitHub Pages

3. Update package.json

  • Remove server dependencies: @react-router/node, @react-router/serve, isbot
  • Remove start script (no server needed)
  • Update build script to copy index.html to 404.html (handles client-side routing on GitHub Pages)
  • Add preview script for local testing of production build

4. Delete Dockerfile (optional)

  • No longer needed for static site deployment

Files to Modify

  • react-router.config.ts
  • vite.config.ts
  • package.json

Files to Delete

  • Dockerfile
  • .dockerignore

Verification

  1. Run npm install to update dependencies
  2. Run npm run dev to verify dev server works
  3. Run npm run build to create static build
  4. Run npm run preview to test production build locally
  5. Verify build/client/ contains static files including 404.html

Please analyze this codebase and create a CLAUDE.md file, which will be given to future instances of Claude Code to operate in this repository.

What to add:

  1. Commands that will be commonly used, such as how to build, lint, and run tests. Include the necessary commands to develop in this codebase, such as how to run a single test.
  2. High-level code architecture and structure so that future instances can be productive more quickly. Focus on the "big picture" architecture that requires reading multiple files to understand.

Usage notes:

  • If there's already a CLAUDE.md, suggest improvements to it.
  • When you make the initial CLAUDE.md, do not repeat yourself and do not include obvious instructions like "Provide helpful error messages to users", "Write unit tests for all new utilities", "Never include sensitive information (API keys, tokens) in code or commits".
  • Avoid listing every component or file structure that can be easily discovered.
  • Don't include generic development practices.
  • If there are Cursor rules (in .cursor/rules/ or .cursorrules) or Copilot rules (in .github/copilot-instructions.md), make sure to include the important parts.
  • If there is a README.md, make sure to include the important parts.
  • Do not make up information such as "Common Development Tasks", "Tips for Development", "Support and Documentation" unless this is expressly included in other files that you read.
  • Be sure to prefix the file with the following text:
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

Codebase Exploration Report for jsquiz

1. Project Type & Framework

...

Perfect! Now I have a comprehensive understanding of the project. Let me create a summary report:

Codebase Exploration Report for jsquiz

1. Project Type & Framework

This is a React Router 7 full-stack web application with the following characteristics:

  • Framework: React Router v7.12.0 (modern, production-ready framework)
  • Language: TypeScript (strict mode enabled)
  • Template: Official React Router template
  • Architecture: Server-side rendering (SSR) enabled by default, with built-in full-stack capabilities
  • UI Framework: React 19.2.4 with React DOM
  • Styling: TailwindCSS v4.1.13

2. Build System & Key Commands

All commands are defined in /home/gback/cs3754/jsquiz/package.json:

Command Purpose
npm run dev Start development server with HMR (Hot Module Replacement) at http://localhost:5173
npm run build Create optimized production build
npm run start Start production server from built assets
npm run typecheck Generate React Router types and run TypeScript compiler

Build System:

  • Build Tool: Vite 7.1.7 (configured in /home/gback/cs3754/jsquiz/vite.config.ts)
  • Bundler: React Router build system (uses @react-router/dev)
  • Output: Built artifacts in /build directory with separate /build/client and /build/server directories

3. High-Level Architecture & Directory Structure

jsquiz/
 app/                          # Application source code
    root.tsx                  # Root layout component with error boundary
    routes.ts                 # Route configuration (React Router v7 file-based routing)
    routes/
       home.tsx              # Home page component
    welcome/
       welcome.tsx           # Welcome component (template starter page)
       logo-dark.svg         # Dark theme logo
       logo-light.svg        # Light theme logo
    app.css                   # Global app styles (TailwindCSS imports)

 public/                       # Static assets
    favicon.ico               # Favicon

 build/                        # Generated build output (git-ignored)
    client/                   # Client-side static assets
    server/                   # Server-side code

 Configuration Files:
    package.json              # Dependencies and scripts
    package-lock.json         # Locked versions
    tsconfig.json             # TypeScript configuration
    vite.config.ts            # Vite build configuration
    react-router.config.ts    # React Router configuration (SSR enabled)
    Dockerfile                # Multi-stage Docker build
    .gitignore                # Git ignore patterns
    .dockerignore             # Docker ignore patterns
    README.md                 # Project documentation

 .git/                         # Git repository

4. Key Architecture Patterns

React Router v7 Features:

  • Type-safe routes: Generated types in .react-router/types/ directory
  • File-based routing: Routes defined via routes.ts configuration
  • Server-side rendering: Enabled by default in react-router.config.ts
  • Automatic type generation: Running npm run typecheck generates types for each route
  • Error boundaries: Root layout includes custom error handling and 404 pages

TypeScript Configuration (tsconfig.json):

  • Target: ES2022
  • Strict mode enabled
  • Path alias: ~/* maps to ./app/*
  • Includes JSX (react-jsx factory)
  • Module resolution: bundler

Build Pipeline:

  • Vite plugins: tailwindcss, reactRouter, tsconfigPaths
  • Separate client and server bundles for SSR
  • TailwindCSS v4 with Vite integration

5. Existing Configuration Files

Present:

  • README.md (/home/gback/cs3754/jsquiz/README.md) - Complete with getting started guide
  • package.json - Defines all scripts and dependencies
  • tsconfig.json - TypeScript configuration
  • vite.config.ts - Vite bundler configuration
  • react-router.config.ts - Framework configuration
  • Dockerfile - Multi-stage Docker build

Not Present:

  • CLAUDE.md - No Claude Code instructions file
  • .cursorrules - No Cursor IDE rules
  • .cursor/rules/ - No Cursor directory
  • .github/copilot-instructions.md - No GitHub Copilot instructions
  • .github/ directory - No GitHub workflows or templates

6. Development Environment Notes

Node/Dependencies:

  • Node.js: v20 (from Dockerfile)
  • Package manager: npm (package-lock.json present)
  • Install command: npm install

Key Dependencies:

  • React Router (main framework)
  • Tailwind CSS (styling)
  • TailwindCSS Vite plugin (Tailwind integration)
  • isbot (user agent detection for SSR)

Git Status:

  • Clean working directory
  • Initial commit from create-react-router template

Summary for New Developers

This is a React Router v7 full-stack application using:

  1. TypeScript for type safety
  2. Vite for fast development and bundling
  3. TailwindCSS for styling
  4. Server-side rendering enabled by default

To get started:

  • Run npm install to install dependencies
  • Run npm run dev to start the development server (localhost:5173)
  • Edit components in /app (e.g., /app/routes/home.tsx)
  • The route configuration is in /app/routes.ts
  • Global styles are in /app/app.css (TailwindCSS)
  • Run npm run build to create a production build

The project follows React Router v7's conventions and is production-ready with Docker support.

# Welcome to React Router!

A modern, production-ready template for building full-stack React applications using React Router.

[![Open in StackBlitz](https://developer.stackblitz.com/img/open_in_stackblitz.svg)](https://stackblitz.com/github/remix-run/react-router-templates/tree/main/default)

# Welcome to React Router!

A modern, production-ready template for building full-stack React applications using React Router.

[![Open in StackBlitz](https://developer.stackblitz.com/img/open_in_stackblitz.svg)](https://stackblitz.com/github/remix-run/react-router-templates/tree/main/default)

## Features

-  Server-side rendering
-  Hot Module Replacement (HMR)
-  Asset bundling and optimization
-  Data loading and mutations
-  TypeScript by default
-  TailwindCSS for styling
-  [React Router docs](https://reactrouter.com/)

## Getting Started

### Installation

Install the dependencies:

```bash
npm install
```

### Development

Start the development server with HMR:

```bash
npm run dev
```

Your application will be available at `http://localhost:5173`.

## Building for Production

Create a production build:

```bash
npm run build
```

## Deployment

### Docker Deployment

To build and run using Docker:

```bash
docker build -t my-app .

# Run the container
docker run -p 3000:3000 my-app
```

The containerized application can be deployed to any platform that supports Docker, including:

- AWS ECS
- Google Cloud Run
- Azure Container Apps
- Digital Ocean App Platform
- Fly.io
- Railway

### DIY Deployment

If you're familiar with deploying Node applications, the built-in app server is production-ready.

Make sure to deploy the output of `npm run build`

```
 package.json
 package-lock.json (or pnpm-lock.yaml, or bun.lockb)
 build/
    client/    # Static assets
    server/    # Server-side code
```

## Styling

This template comes with [Tailwind CSS](https://tailwindcss.com/) already configured for a simple default starting experience. You can use whatever CSS framework you prefer.

---

Built with  using React Router.
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.

import {
  isRouteErrorResponse,
  Links,
  Meta,
  Outlet,
  Scripts,
  ScrollRestoration,
} from "react-router";

import type { Route } from "./+types/root";
import "./app.css";

export const links: Route.LinksFunction = () => [
  { rel: "preconnect", href: "https://fonts.googleapis.com" },
  {
    rel: "preconnect",
    href: "https://fonts.gstatic.com",
    crossOrigin: "anonymous",
  },
  {
    rel: "stylesheet",
    href: "https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Inter:ital,opsz,wght@0,14..32,100..900;1,14..32,100..900&display=swap",
  },
];

export function Layout({ children }: { children: React.ReactNode }) {
  return (
    <html lang="en">
      <head>
        <meta charSet="utf-8" />
        <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1" />
        <Meta />
        <Links />
      </head>
      <body>
        {children}
        <ScrollRestoration />
        <Scripts />
      </body>
    </html>
  );
}

export default function App() {
  return <Outlet />;
}

export function ErrorBoundary({ error }: Route.ErrorBoundaryProps) {
  let message = "Oops!";
  let details = "An unexpected error occurred.";
  let stack: string | undefined;

  if (isRouteErrorResponse(error)) {
    message = error.status === 404 ? "404" : "Error";
    details =
      error.status === 404
        ? "The requested page could not be found."
        : error.statusText || details;
  } else if (import.meta.env.DEV && error && error instanceof Error) {
    details = error.message;
    stack = error.stack;
  }

  return (
    <main className="pt-16 p-4 container mx-auto">
      <h1>{message}</h1>
      <p>{details}</p>
      {stack && (
        <pre className="w-full p-4 overflow-x-auto">
          <code>{stack}</code>
        </pre>
      )}
    </main>
  );
}
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.

    "moduleResolution": "bundler",

    "baseUrl": ".",
    "paths": {
      "~/*": ["./app/*"]
    },
    "esModuleInterop": true,
    "verbatimModuleSyntax": true,
    "noEmit": true,
    "resolveJsonModule": true,
    "skipLibCheck": true,
    "strict": true
  }
}

# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Commands
 
 1

# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Commands

- `npm run dev` - Start development server with HMR at http://localhost:5173
- `npm run build` - Create production build
- `npm run start` - Start production server
- `npm run typecheck` - Generate React Router types and run TypeScript compiler

## Architecture

This is a React Router v7 full-stack application with server-side rendering enabled.

**Key Technologies:**
- React Router v7 (framework)
- React 19
- TypeScript (strict mode)
- TailwindCSS v4
- Vite (build tool)

**Project Structure:**
- `app/` - Application source code
  - `root.tsx` - Root layout with error boundary
  - `routes.ts` - Route configuration
  - `routes/` - Route components
  - `app.css` - Global styles (TailwindCSS)
- `build/` - Generated build output (client/ and server/ bundles)
- `public/` - Static assets

**React Router v7 Conventions:**
- Routes are defined in `app/routes.ts` using the `RouteConfig` type
- Type-safe routes are generated in `.react-router/types/` (run `npm run typecheck` to generate)
- Route types are imported as `import type { Route } from "./+types/[route-name]"`
- Path alias `~/*` maps to `./app/*`
2026-01-27 04:55:46 
File created successfully at: /home/gback/cs3754/jsquiz/CLAUDE.md ...
Assistant
2026-01-27 04:55:50
Input: 1 | Output: 1 | Cache Creation: 495 | Cache Read: 23039

I've created the CLAUDE.md file with the essential information for working with this React Router v7 codebase. The file includes:

  1. Commands - The key npm scripts for development, building, and type checking
  2. Architecture - Key technologies and project structure overview
  3. React Router v7 Conventions - The framework-specific patterns that are important to understand (route configuration, type generation, path aliases)

The file is concise and focuses on what's unique to this project rather than generic development practices. It avoids listing every file since the structure is discoverable, and focuses on the "big picture" patterns that require understanding the framework.

2026-01-27 04:56:17 
I'd like to build an SPA, with no SSR and no API, suitable for deployment on github page (github.io).
2 thoughts
6 tools, 2 thoughts total

2026-01-27 04:56:22
Input: 10 | Output: 5 | Cache Creation: 6103 | Cache Read: 17778

The user wants to convert this React Router v7 app from an SSR full-stack application to a client-side only SPA (Single Page Application) that can be deployed on GitHub Pages. This means:

  1. Disable SSR - React Router v7 has a configuration option for this
  2. Configure for static file output - GitHub Pages serves static files
  3. Handle client-side routing for GitHub Pages (which doesn't have server-side routing)

Let me check the react-router.config.ts to see the current configuration and understand what needs to change.

import type { Config } from "@react-router/dev/config";

export default {
  // Config options...
  // Server-side render by default, to enable SPA mode set this to `false`
  ssr: true,
} satisfies Config;

import tsconfigPaths from "vite-tsconfig-paths";

  plugins: [tailwindcss(), reactRouter(), tsconfigPaths()],

2026-01-27 04:56:28
Input: 8 | Output: 1 | Cache Creation: 1384 | Cache Read: 23881

Now I understand the current setup. To convert this to a static SPA for GitHub Pages, I need to:

  1. Set ssr: false in react-router.config.ts
  2. Configure the base path in vite.config.ts (for GitHub Pages, if deploying to a project page like username.github.io/repo-name, need to set base to /repo-name/)
  3. Remove server-side dependencies that won't be needed (@react-router/node, @react-router/serve, isbot)
  4. Update the start script since there's no server to run
  5. For GitHub Pages with client-side routing, we need to handle the 404 fallback - typically by copying index.html to 404.html

Let me make these changes.

Assistant
2026-01-27 04:56:29

I'll configure the app for static SPA deployment on GitHub Pages.

+ ssr: false,

- // Server-side render by default, to enable SPA mode set this to `false`
- ssr: true,

# Plan: Convert to Static SPA for GitHub Pages

## Goal
Convert the React Router v7 app from SSR to a client-only SPA deployable on GitHub Pages (username.github.io/jsquiz).

# Plan: Convert to Static SPA for GitHub Pages

## Goal
Convert the React Router v7 app from SSR to a client-only SPA deployable on GitHub Pages (username.github.io/jsquiz).

## Changes Required

### 1. Disable SSR (`react-router.config.ts`)
- Set `ssr: false`
- Add `basename: "/jsquiz/"` for GitHub Pages project path

### 2. Configure Vite base path (`vite.config.ts`)
- Add `base: "/jsquiz/"` for correct asset URLs on GitHub Pages

### 3. Update package.json
- Remove server dependencies: `@react-router/node`, `@react-router/serve`, `isbot`
- Remove `start` script (no server needed)
- Update `build` script to copy `index.html` to `404.html` (handles client-side routing on GitHub Pages)
- Add `preview` script for local testing of production build

### 4. Delete Dockerfile (optional)
- No longer needed for static site deployment

## Files to Modify
- `react-router.config.ts`
- `vite.config.ts`
- `package.json`

## Files to Delete (optional)
- `Dockerfile`
- `.dockerignore`

## Verification
1. Run `npm install` to update dependencies
2. Run `npm run dev` to verify dev server works
3. Run `npm run build` to create static build
4. Run `npm run preview` to test production build locally
5. Verify `build/client/` contains static files including `404.html`

  • User site (root) Deployed at username.github.io - no base path needed

  • No, keep them Keep Docker files in case you want them later

Plan: Convert to Static SPA for GitHub Pages

Goal

Convert the React Router v7 app from SSR to a client-only SPA deployable on GitHub Pages (username.github.io/jsquiz).

Changes Required

1. Disable SSR (react-router.config.ts)

  • Set ssr: false
  • Add basename: "/jsquiz/" for GitHub Pages project path

2. Configure Vite base path (vite.config.ts)

  • Add base: "/jsquiz/" for correct asset URLs on GitHub Pages

3. Update package.json

  • Remove server dependencies: @react-router/node, @react-router/serve, isbot
  • Remove start script (no server needed)
  • Update build script to copy index.html to 404.html (handles client-side routing on GitHub Pages)
  • Add preview script for local testing of production build

4. Delete Dockerfile (optional)

  • No longer needed for static site deployment

Files to Modify

  • react-router.config.ts
  • vite.config.ts
  • package.json

Files to Delete

  • Dockerfile
  • .dockerignore

Verification

  1. Run npm install to update dependencies
  2. Run npm run dev to verify dev server works
  3. Run npm run build to create static build
  4. Run npm run preview to test production build locally
  5. Verify build/client/ contains static files including 404.html

Implement the following plan:

# Plan: Convert to Static SPA for GitHub Pages

## Goal
Convert the React Router v7 app from SSR to a client-only SPA deployable on GitHub Pages (username.github.io/jsquiz).

## Changes Required

### 1. Disable SSR (`react-router.config.ts`)
- Set `ssr: false`
- Add `basename: "/jsquiz/"` for GitHub Pages project path

### 2. Configure Vite base path (`vite.config.ts`)
- Add `base: "/jsquiz/"` for correct asset URLs on GitHub Pages

### 3. Update package.json
- Remove server dependencies: `@react-router/node`, `@react-router/serve`, `isbot`
- Remove `start` script (no server needed)
- Update `build` script to copy `index.html` to `404.html` (handles client-side routing on GitHub Pages)
- Add `preview` script for local testing of production build

### 4. Delete Dockerfile (optional)
- No longer needed for static site deployment

## Files to Modify
- `react-router.config.ts`
- `vite.config.ts`
- `package.json`

## Files to Delete
- `Dockerfile`
- `.dockerignore`

## Verification
1. Run `npm install` to update dependencies
2. Run `npm run dev` to verify dev server works
3. Run `npm run build` to create static build
4. Run `npm run preview` to test production build locally
5. Verify `build/client/` contains static files including `404.html`


If you need specific details from before exiting plan mode (like exact code snippets, error messages, or content you generated), read the full transcript at: /home/gback/.claude/projects/-home-gback-cs3754-jsquiz/7df30b9d-35da-4d75-8cd0-094583bfa6fe.jsonl

Let's make a plan and write the plan in PLAN.md
I would like to create a pure SPA (no SSR, no API even) suitable for hosting on github page (godmar.githubio/jsquiz)
I would like to use React and Material UI
The SPA should provide a 10-question quiz on intermediate JavaScript
(no TypeScript)
It should include the instructions for the necessary github workflow/actions to publish it as github pages.
Because it's hosted on github, it should use a hash router (github doesn't support SPA redirection/fallback)
I'm thinking of using React Router in pure client SPA mode.

Design an implementation plan for a pure SPA JavaScript quiz application with these requirements:


Requirements:


    

  • Pure SPA (no SSR, no API) for GitHub Pages hosting at godmar.github.io/jsquiz
    • 

  • React with Material UI
    • 



...



        
        
Design an implementation plan for a pure SPA JavaScript quiz application with these requirements:


Requirements:


    

  • Pure SPA (no SSR, no API) for GitHub Pages hosting at godmar.github.io/jsquiz
    • 

  • React with Material UI
    • 

  • Plain JavaScript (no TypeScript)
    • 

  • 10-question quiz on intermediate JavaScript topics
    • 

  • HashRouter from React Router (GitHub Pages doesn't support SPA fallback)
    • 

  • GitHub Actions workflow for deployment
    • 



Design considerations:


    

  1. Build tool: Recommend Vite (modern, fast) vs Create React App (deprecated). Vite with @vitejs/plugin-react supports JSX without TypeScript.
    

    2. 

  2. Project structure: Design a clean folder structure for:
    

      

    • Components (Quiz, Question, Results, etc.)
      • 

    • Quiz data (questions stored as JSON or JS module)
      • 

    • Routing setup
      • 

    

    3. 

  3. Quiz UX flow:
    

      

    • Start screen with instructions
      • 

    • Question-by-question navigation (or all at once?)
      • 

    • Progress indicator
      • 

    • Results page with score
      • 

    

    4. 

  4. Quiz question format: Define the data structure for questions (multiple choice, code snippets, explanations)
    

    5. 

  5. Material UI components: Which MUI components to use (Card, Button, Radio, LinearProgress, etc.)
    

    6. 

  6. GitHub Actions workflow:
    

      

    • Build the app
      • 

    • Deploy to gh-pages branch
      • 

    • Handle the base path correctly for godmar.github.io/jsquiz
      • 

    

    7. 

  7. Vite config: Configure base path for GitHub Pages subdirectory deployment
    

    8. 



Provide a detailed implementation plan with file structure and key code patterns.



    

        
    

    
    
    
    
    

        

            
            

                

                    2026-01-27 05:12:42
                

                
            

        

        

        
            727 lines
            
I now have comprehensive information to create a detailed implementation plan. Let me compile all the research into a complete design document.




Implementation Plan: JavaScript Quiz SPA


...



        
        
I now have comprehensive information to create a detailed implementation plan. Let me compile all the research into a complete design document.




Implementation Plan: JavaScript Quiz SPA


Overview


This plan outlines the implementation of a pure Single Page Application (SPA) quiz for intermediate JavaScript topics, built with Vite, React, and Material UI, deployed to GitHub Pages at godmar.github.io/jsquiz.




1. Build Tool Selection: Vite


Recommendation: Vite (not Create React App)


Rationale:


    

  • Create React App is officially deprecated as of 2023
    • 

  • Vite is the recommended modern build tool by the React team
    • 

  • Vite provides faster dev server startup and hot module replacement
    • 

  • The @vitejs/plugin-react plugin handles JSX transformation without requiring TypeScript
    • 

  • MUI officially recommends Vite for SPAs (per MUI documentation)
    • 





2. Project Structure


jsquiz/
 .github/
    workflows/
        deploy.yml          # GitHub Actions workflow
 public/
    favicon.ico             # Optional favicon
 src/
    components/
       Quiz/
          Quiz.jsx        # Main quiz container
          StartScreen.jsx # Welcome/instructions screen
          Question.jsx    # Individual question display
          QuestionNav.jsx # Navigation between questions
          Results.jsx     # Final score and review
       common/
           Header.jsx      # App header/title bar
           ProgressBar.jsx # Quiz progress indicator
    data/
       questions.js        # Quiz questions data
    hooks/
       useQuiz.js          # Quiz state management hook
    theme/
       theme.js            # MUI theme customization
    App.jsx                 # Main app with routing
    main.jsx                # Entry point
    index.css               # Global styles (minimal)
 index.html                  # HTML template
 package.json
 vite.config.js              # Vite configuration
 README.md





3. Package Dependencies


package.json dependencies:


{
  "name": "jsquiz",
  "private": true,
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "type": "module",
  "scripts": {
    "dev": "vite",
    "build": "vite build",
    "preview": "vite preview"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "@emotion/react": "^11.11.0",
    "@emotion/styled": "^11.11.0",
    "@mui/material": "^5.15.0",
    "@mui/icons-material": "^5.15.0",
    "react": "^18.2.0",
    "react-dom": "^18.2.0",
    "react-router-dom": "^6.21.0"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "@vitejs/plugin-react": "^4.2.0",
    "vite": "^5.0.0"
  }
}





4. Vite Configuration for GitHub Pages


vite.config.js:


import { defineConfig } from 'vite';
import react from '@vitejs/plugin-react';

export default defineConfig({
  plugins: [react()],
  base: '/jsquiz/',  // Critical for GitHub Pages subdirectory
});



The base path must match the repository name for correct asset loading at godmar.github.io/jsquiz.




5. Quiz Data Structure


src/data/questions.js:


const questions = [
  {
    id: 1,
    question: "What is the output of the following code?",
    code: `console.log(typeof null);`,
    options: [
      { id: 'a', text: '"null"' },
      { id: 'b', text: '"undefined"' },
      { id: 'c', text: '"object"' },
      { id: 'd', text: 'TypeError' }
    ],
    correctAnswer: 'c',
    explanation: "This is a known JavaScript quirk. typeof null returns 'object' due to a bug in the original JavaScript implementation that was never fixed for backward compatibility.",
    topic: "Types",
    difficulty: "intermediate"
  },
  {
    id: 2,
    question: "What will be logged to the console?",
    code: `for (var i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
  setTimeout(() => console.log(i), 1);
}`,
    options: [
      { id: 'a', text: '0 1 2' },
      { id: 'b', text: '3 3 3' },
      { id: 'c', text: '0 0 0' },
      { id: 'd', text: 'undefined undefined undefined' }
    ],
    correctAnswer: 'b',
    explanation: "var is function-scoped, not block-scoped. By the time the setTimeout callbacks execute, the loop has completed and i equals 3. Using let instead of var would log 0 1 2.",
    topic: "Closures & Scope",
    difficulty: "intermediate"
  },
  // ... 8 more questions covering:
  // - Promises and async/await
  // - Array methods (map, filter, reduce)
  // - Object destructuring
  // - Spread operator
  // - this keyword binding
  // - Event loop
  // - Hoisting
  // - Equality operators (== vs ===)
];

export default questions;





6. Application Entry Point and Routing


src/main.jsx:


import React from 'react';
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom/client';
import { HashRouter } from 'react-router-dom';
import { ThemeProvider } from '@mui/material/styles';
import CssBaseline from '@mui/material/CssBaseline';
import App from './App';
import theme from './theme/theme';

ReactDOM.createRoot(document.getElementById('root')).render(
  <React.StrictMode>
    <HashRouter>
      <ThemeProvider theme={theme}>
        <CssBaseline />
        <App />
      </ThemeProvider>
    </HashRouter>
  </React.StrictMode>
);



Why HashRouter: GitHub Pages serves static files and does not support SPA fallback routing. HashRouter uses the URL hash (#/path) which works without server configuration. URLs will look like godmar.github.io/jsquiz/#/quiz.


src/App.jsx:


import { Routes, Route } from 'react-router-dom';
import { Container } from '@mui/material';
import Header from './components/common/Header';
import StartScreen from './components/Quiz/StartScreen';
import Quiz from './components/Quiz/Quiz';
import Results from './components/Quiz/Results';

function App() {
  return (
    <>
      <Header />
      <Container maxWidth="md" sx={{ py: 4 }}>
        <Routes>
          <Route path="/" element={<StartScreen />} />
          <Route path="/quiz" element={<Quiz />} />
          <Route path="/results" element={<Results />} />
        </Routes>
      </Container>
    </>
  );
}

export default App;





7. Quiz UX Flow


Flow Design:


    

  1. Start Screen (/) - Instructions, topic overview, "Start Quiz" button
    2. 

  2. Quiz Screen (/quiz) - One question at a time with navigation
    3. 

  3. Results Screen (/results) - Final score, question review with explanations
    4. 



Question Navigation Pattern:


    

  • Show one question at a time (reduces cognitive load)
    • 

  • Previous/Next buttons for navigation
    • 

  • Allow revisiting answered questions
    • 

  • Progress bar showing completion status
    • 

  • "Submit Quiz" button appears on last question or as persistent option
    • 





8. Key Component Implementations


src/components/Quiz/StartScreen.jsx:


import { useNavigate } from 'react-router-dom';
import { Box, Typography, Button, Card, CardContent, List, ListItem, ListItemIcon, ListItemText } from '@mui/material';
import { Quiz as QuizIcon, Timer, CheckCircle } from '@mui/icons-material';

function StartScreen() {
  const navigate = useNavigate();

  return (
    <Card>
      <CardContent>
        <Typography variant="h4" component="h1" gutterBottom>
          JavaScript Quiz
        </Typography>
        <Typography variant="subtitle1" color="text.secondary" paragraph>
          Test your intermediate JavaScript knowledge
        </Typography>
        
        <List>
          <ListItem>
            <ListItemIcon><QuizIcon /></ListItemIcon>
            <ListItemText primary="10 multiple choice questions" />
          </ListItem>
          <ListItem>
            <ListItemIcon><Timer /></ListItemIcon>
            <ListItemText primary="No time limit - take your time" />
          </ListItem>
          <ListItem>
            <ListItemIcon><CheckCircle /></ListItemIcon>
            <ListItemText primary="Review explanations after submission" />
          </ListItem>
        </List>

        <Box sx={{ mt: 3, textAlign: 'center' }}>
          <Button 
            variant="contained" 
            size="large"
            onClick={() => navigate('/quiz')}
          >
            Start Quiz
          </Button>
        </Box>
      </CardContent>
    </Card>
  );
}

export default StartScreen;



src/hooks/useQuiz.js:


import { useState, useCallback } from 'react';
import questions from '../data/questions';

function useQuiz() {
  const [currentIndex, setCurrentIndex] = useState(0);
  const [answers, setAnswers] = useState({});
  const [isSubmitted, setIsSubmitted] = useState(false);

  const currentQuestion = questions[currentIndex];
  const totalQuestions = questions.length;
  const progress = ((currentIndex + 1) / totalQuestions) * 100;

  const selectAnswer = useCallback((questionId, answerId) => {
    setAnswers(prev => ({ ...prev, [questionId]: answerId }));
  }, []);

  const goToNext = useCallback(() => {
    if (currentIndex < totalQuestions - 1) {
      setCurrentIndex(prev => prev + 1);
    }
  }, [currentIndex, totalQuestions]);

  const goToPrevious = useCallback(() => {
    if (currentIndex > 0) {
      setCurrentIndex(prev => prev - 1);
    }
  }, [currentIndex]);

  const goToQuestion = useCallback((index) => {
    setCurrentIndex(index);
  }, []);

  const submitQuiz = useCallback(() => {
    setIsSubmitted(true);
  }, []);

  const calculateScore = useCallback(() => {
    return questions.reduce((score, q) => {
      return answers[q.id] === q.correctAnswer ? score + 1 : score;
    }, 0);
  }, [answers]);

  const resetQuiz = useCallback(() => {
    setCurrentIndex(0);
    setAnswers({});
    setIsSubmitted(false);
  }, []);

  return {
    currentQuestion,
    currentIndex,
    totalQuestions,
    progress,
    answers,
    isSubmitted,
    selectAnswer,
    goToNext,
    goToPrevious,
    goToQuestion,
    submitQuiz,
    calculateScore,
    resetQuiz,
    questions
  };
}

export default useQuiz;



src/components/Quiz/Question.jsx:


import { Card, CardContent, Typography, Box, RadioGroup, FormControlLabel, Radio } from '@mui/material';

function Question({ question, selectedAnswer, onSelectAnswer, showResult }) {
  const isCorrect = selectedAnswer === question.correctAnswer;

  return (
    <Card>
      <CardContent>
        <Typography variant="h6" gutterBottom>
          {question.question}
        </Typography>
        
        {question.code && (
          <Box
            component="pre"
            sx={{
              bgcolor: 'grey.900',
              color: 'grey.100',
              p: 2,
              borderRadius: 1,
              overflow: 'auto',
              fontFamily: 'monospace',
              fontSize: '0.875rem',
              my: 2
            }}
          >
            <code>{question.code}</code>
          </Box>
        )}

        <RadioGroup
          value={selectedAnswer || ''}
          onChange={(e) => onSelectAnswer(question.id, e.target.value)}
        >
          {question.options.map((option) => {
            let color = 'inherit';
            if (showResult) {
              if (option.id === question.correctAnswer) color = 'success.main';
              else if (option.id === selectedAnswer) color = 'error.main';
            }
            
            return (
              <FormControlLabel
                key={option.id}
                value={option.id}
                control={<Radio disabled={showResult} />}
                label={option.text}
                sx={{ color }}
              />
            );
          })}
        </RadioGroup>

        {showResult && (
          <Box sx={{ mt: 2, p: 2, bgcolor: isCorrect ? 'success.light' : 'error.light', borderRadius: 1 }}>
            <Typography variant="body2">
              {isCorrect ? 'Correct!' : 'Incorrect.'} {question.explanation}
            </Typography>
          </Box>
        )}
      </CardContent>
    </Card>
  );
}

export default Question;



src/components/Quiz/Results.jsx:


import { useNavigate, useLocation } from 'react-router-dom';
import { Box, Typography, Button, Card, CardContent, LinearProgress, Divider } from '@mui/material';
import Question from './Question';

function Results() {
  const navigate = useNavigate();
  const location = useLocation();
  const { score, total, answers, questions } = location.state || {};

  if (!score && score !== 0) {
    navigate('/');
    return null;
  }

  const percentage = Math.round((score / total) * 100);

  return (
    <Box>
      <Card sx={{ mb: 3 }}>
        <CardContent>
          <Typography variant="h4" gutterBottom>
            Quiz Complete!
          </Typography>
          <Typography variant="h5" color="primary">
            Score: {score} / {total} ({percentage}%)
          </Typography>
          <LinearProgress 
            variant="determinate" 
            value={percentage} 
            sx={{ mt: 2, height: 10, borderRadius: 5 }}
          />
          <Box sx={{ mt: 3 }}>
            <Button variant="contained" onClick={() => navigate('/')}>
              Try Again
            </Button>
          </Box>
        </CardContent>
      </Card>

      <Typography variant="h5" gutterBottom sx={{ mt: 4 }}>
        Review Your Answers
      </Typography>
      <Divider sx={{ mb: 2 }} />

      {questions.map((question, index) => (
        <Box key={question.id} sx={{ mb: 2 }}>
          <Typography variant="subtitle2" color="text.secondary" gutterBottom>
            Question {index + 1}
          </Typography>
          <Question
            question={question}
            selectedAnswer={answers[question.id]}
            showResult={true}
            onSelectAnswer={() => {}}
          />
        </Box>
      ))}
    </Box>
  );
}

export default Results;





9. Material UI Components Used






  Component
  Purpose






  Container
  Responsive max-width container




  Card, CardContent
  Question and result cards




  Typography
  All text with consistent styling




  Button
  Navigation and actions




  RadioGroup, Radio, FormControlLabel
  Answer selection




  LinearProgress
  Quiz progress indicator




  Box
  Layout and spacing




  List, ListItem, ListItemIcon, ListItemText
  Start screen feature list




  AppBar, Toolbar
  Header component




  Divider
  Visual separation




  Icons from @mui/icons-material
  Visual enhancements








10. MUI Theme Customization


src/theme/theme.js:


import { createTheme } from '@mui/material/styles';

const theme = createTheme({
  palette: {
    primary: {
      main: '#f7df1e',  // JavaScript yellow
      contrastText: '#000',
    },
    secondary: {
      main: '#323330',  // JavaScript dark
    },
    background: {
      default: '#f5f5f5',
    },
  },
  typography: {
    fontFamily: '"Roboto", "Helvetica", "Arial", sans-serif',
    h4: {
      fontWeight: 600,
    },
  },
  components: {
    MuiCard: {
      styleOverrides: {
        root: {
          borderRadius: 12,
        },
      },
    },
    MuiButton: {
      styleOverrides: {
        root: {
          borderRadius: 8,
          textTransform: 'none',
        },
      },
    },
  },
});

export default theme;





11. GitHub Actions Workflow


.github/workflows/deploy.yml:


name: Deploy to GitHub Pages

on:
  push:
    branches: ['main']
  workflow_dispatch:

permissions:
  contents: read
  pages: write
  id-token: write

concurrency:
  group: 'pages'
  cancel-in-progress: true

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Setup Node.js
        uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: '20'
          cache: 'npm'

      - name: Install dependencies
        run: npm ci

      - name: Build
        run: npm run build

      - name: Setup Pages
        uses: actions/configure-pages@v4

      - name: Upload artifact
        uses: actions/upload-pages-artifact@v3
        with:
          path: './dist'

  deploy:
    environment:
      name: github-pages
      url: ${{ steps.deployment.outputs.page_url }}
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: build
    steps:
      - name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
        id: deployment
        uses: actions/deploy-pages@v4



Repository Settings Required:


    

  1. Go to Settings > Pages
    2. 

  2. Under "Build and deployment", select "GitHub Actions" as the source
    3. 





12. HTML Entry Point


index.html:


<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
  <head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8" />
    <link rel="icon" type="image/svg+xml" href="/favicon.ico" />
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0" />
    <meta name="description" content="Test your intermediate JavaScript knowledge with this interactive quiz" />
    <title>JavaScript Quiz</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <div id="root"></div>
    <script type="module" src="/src/main.jsx"></script>
  </body>
</html>





13. Sample Quiz Questions (10 Intermediate Topics)


The quiz should cover these intermediate JavaScript topics:


    

  1. typeof null quirk - Understanding JavaScript's type system bugs
    2. 

  2. var vs let in loops - Closure and scope behavior
    3. 

  3. Promise.all behavior - Promise combinators
    4. 

  4. Array reduce - Functional array methods
    5. 

  5. Object destructuring with defaults - ES6 destructuring
    6. 

  6. Spread operator limitations - Shallow vs deep copy
    7. 

  7. this in arrow functions - Execution context
    8. 

  8. Event loop order - setTimeout vs Promise microtasks
    9. 

  9. Hoisting behavior - Variable and function hoisting
    10. 

  10. Strict equality - == vs === coercion rules
    11. 





14. Implementation Sequence


    

  1. Phase 1: Project Setup
    

      

    • Initialize Vite project with React template
      • 

    • Install MUI and React Router dependencies
      • 

    • Configure vite.config.js with base path
      • 

    

    2. 

  2. Phase 2: Core Structure
    

      

    • Set up routing with HashRouter
      • 

    • Create theme configuration
      • 

    • Build basic component shells
      • 

    

    3. 

  3. Phase 3: Quiz Logic
    

      

    • Implement useQuiz hook for state management
      • 

    • Create questions data file
      • 

    • Wire up question navigation
      • 

    

    4. 

  4. Phase 4: UI Polish
    

      

    • Style all components with MUI
      • 

    • Add progress indicator
      • 

    • Implement results review screen
      • 

    

    5. 

  5. Phase 5: Deployment
    

      

    • Create GitHub Actions workflow
      • 

    • Configure repository Pages settings
      • 

    • Test deployment
      • 

    

    6.

    •

    •

    •

## Overview

# JavaScript Quiz SPA - Implementation Plan

## Overview
Create a pure SPA quiz application for intermediate JavaScript, deployed to GitHub Pages at `godmar.github.io/jsquiz`.

**Tech Stack:**
- Vite (build tool) - modern, fast, recommended over deprecated CRA
- React 18 (plain JavaScript, no TypeScript)
- Material UI 5 (styling)
- React Router 6 with HashRouter (GitHub Pages compatible)

---

## Project Structure

```
jsquiz/
 .github/workflows/deploy.yml   # GitHub Actions deployment
 public/
 src/
    components/
       Quiz/
          Quiz.jsx           # Main quiz container
          StartScreen.jsx    # Welcome + instructions
          Question.jsx       # Single question display
          Results.jsx        # Score + review
       common/
           Header.jsx         # App header
    data/
       questions.js           # 10 quiz questions
    hooks/
       useQuiz.js             # Quiz state management
    theme/
       theme.js               # MUI theme (JS yellow colors)
    App.jsx                    # Routes configuration
    main.jsx                   # Entry point with providers
 index.html
 package.json
 vite.config.js                 # base: '/jsquiz/' for GH Pages
 README.md
```

---

## Implementation Steps

### 1. Initialize Project
```bash
npm create vite@latest . -- --template react
npm install @mui/material @emotion/react @emotion/styled @mui/icons-material react-router-dom
```

### 2. Configure Vite for GitHub Pages
**vite.config.js:**
```javascript
import { defineConfig } from 'vite';
import react from '@vitejs/plugin-react';

export default defineConfig({
  plugins: [react()],
  base: '/jsquiz/',  // Critical for GH Pages subdirectory
});
```

### 3. Set Up HashRouter
**src/main.jsx:**
```javascript
import { HashRouter } from 'react-router-dom';
// URLs will be: godmar.github.io/jsquiz/#/quiz
```

### 4. Create Quiz Data Structure
**src/data/questions.js** - 10 intermediate JS questions covering:
1. `typeof null` quirk
2. `var` vs `let` in loops (closures)
3. Promise.all behavior
4. Array reduce
5. Object destructuring with defaults
6. Spread operator (shallow copy)
7. `this` in arrow functions
8. Event loop (setTimeout vs microtasks)
9. Hoisting behavior
10. `==` vs `===` coercion

Each question format:
```javascript
{
  id: 1,
  question: "What is the output?",
  code: `console.log(typeof null);`,
  options: [
    { id: 'a', text: '"null"' },
    { id: 'b', text: '"object"' },
    // ...
  ],
  correctAnswer: 'b',
  explanation: "This is a known JavaScript bug..."
}
```

### 5. Implement Quiz Hook (useQuiz.js)
State management for:
- Current question index
- User answers (object: `{questionId: answerId}`)
- Navigation (next/previous/goTo)
- Score calculation
- Submit and reset

### 6. Build Components
- **StartScreen**: Instructions, feature list, "Start Quiz" button
- **Quiz**: Progress bar, Question component, nav buttons
- **Question**: Code block, radio group for options
- **Results**: Score display, question review with explanations

### 7. Create GitHub Actions Workflow
**.github/workflows/deploy.yml:**
```yaml
name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
on:
  push:
    branches: ['main']
permissions:
  contents: read
  pages: write
  id-token: write
jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: '20'
          cache: 'npm'
      - run: npm ci
      - run: npm run build
      - uses: actions/configure-pages@v4
      - uses: actions/upload-pages-artifact@v3
        with:
          path: './dist'
  deploy:
    environment:
      name: github-pages
      url: ${{ steps.deployment.outputs.page_url }}
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: build
    steps:
      - uses: actions/deploy-pages@v4
        id: deployment
```

---

## Quiz UX Flow

1. **Start Screen** (`/#/`) - Instructions, "Start Quiz" button
2. **Quiz** (`/#/quiz`) - One question at a time, progress bar, prev/next nav
3. **Results** (`/#/results`) - Score, percentage, full review with explanations

---

## Key MUI Components
- `Container`, `Card`, `CardContent` - Layout
- `Typography` - Text styling
- `Button` - Actions
- `RadioGroup`, `Radio`, `FormControlLabel` - Answer selection
- `LinearProgress` - Progress indicator
- `AppBar`, `Toolbar` - Header
- `Box` - Spacing and layout

---

## Repository Setup (Manual Steps)
After pushing code:
1. Go to repo Settings > Pages
2. Under "Build and deployment", select **GitHub Actions** as source
3. Push to `main` branch triggers deployment

---

## Verification
1. Run `npm run dev` - test locally at `localhost:5173/jsquiz/`
2. Test all routes work with HashRouter
3. Push to GitHub, verify Actions workflow runs
4. Check deployed site at `godmar.github.io/jsquiz`

JavaScript Quiz SPA - Implementation Plan


Overview


Create a pure SPA quiz application for intermediate JavaScript, deployed to GitHub Pages at godmar.github.io/jsquiz.


Tech Stack:


    

  • Vite (build tool) - modern, fast, recommended over deprecated CRA
    • 

  • React 18 (plain JavaScript, no TypeScript)
    • 

  • Material UI 5 (styling)
    • 

  • React Router 6 with HashRouter (GitHub Pages compatible)
    • 





Project Structure


jsquiz/
 .github/workflows/deploy.yml   # GitHub Actions deployment
 public/
 src/
    components/
       Quiz/
          Quiz.jsx           # Main quiz container
          StartScreen.jsx    # Welcome + instructions
          Question.jsx       # Single question display
          Results.jsx        # Score + review
       common/
           Header.jsx         # App header
    data/
       questions.js           # 10 quiz questions
    hooks/
       useQuiz.js             # Quiz state management
    theme/
       theme.js               # MUI theme (JS yellow colors)
    App.jsx                    # Routes configuration
    main.jsx                   # Entry point with providers
 index.html
 package.json
 vite.config.js                 # base: '/jsquiz/' for GH Pages
 README.md





Implementation Steps


1. Initialize Project


npm create vite@latest . -- --template react
npm install @mui/material @emotion/react @emotion/styled @mui/icons-material react-router-dom



2. Configure Vite for GitHub Pages


vite.config.js:


import { defineConfig } from 'vite';
import react from '@vitejs/plugin-react';

export default defineConfig({
  plugins: [react()],
  base: '/jsquiz/',  // Critical for GH Pages subdirectory
});



3. Set Up HashRouter


src/main.jsx:


import { HashRouter } from 'react-router-dom';
// URLs will be: godmar.github.io/jsquiz/#/quiz



4. Create Quiz Data Structure


src/data/questions.js - 10 intermediate JS questions covering:


    

  1. typeof null quirk
    2. 

  2. var vs let in loops (closures)
    3. 

  3. Promise.all behavior
    4. 

  4. Array reduce
    5. 

  5. Object destructuring with defaults
    6. 

  6. Spread operator (shallow copy)
    7. 

  7. this in arrow functions
    8. 

  8. Event loop (setTimeout vs microtasks)
    9. 

  9. Hoisting behavior
    10. 

  10. == vs === coercion
    11. 



Each question format:


{
  id: 1,
  question: "What is the output?",
  code: `console.log(typeof null);`,
  options: [
    { id: 'a', text: '"null"' },
    { id: 'b', text: '"object"' },
    // ...
  ],
  correctAnswer: 'b',
  explanation: "This is a known JavaScript bug..."
}



5. Implement Quiz Hook (useQuiz.js)


State management for:


    

  • Current question index
    • 

  • User answers (object: {questionId: answerId})
    • 

  • Navigation (next/previous/goTo)
    • 

  • Score calculation
    • 

  • Submit and reset
    • 



6. Build Components


    

  • StartScreen: Instructions, feature list, "Start Quiz" button

  • Quiz: Progress bar, Question component, nav buttons
    • 

  • Question: Code block, radio group for options
    • 

  • Results: Score display, question review with explanations
    •

name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
on:
  push:
    branches: ['main']
permissions:
  contents: read
  pages: write
  id-token: write
jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: '20'
          cache: 'npm'
      - run: npm ci
      - run: npm run build
      - uses: actions/configure-pages@v4
      - uses: actions/upload-pages-artifact@v3
        with:
          path: './dist'
  deploy:
    environment:
      name: github-pages
      url: ${{ steps.deployment.outputs.page_url }}
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: build
    steps:
      - uses: actions/deploy-pages@v4
        id: deployment

Implement the following plan:

# JavaScript Quiz SPA - Implementation Plan

## Overview
Create a pure SPA quiz application for intermediate JavaScript, deployed to GitHub Pages at `godmar.github.io/jsquiz`.

**Tech Stack:**
- Vite (build tool) - modern, fast, recommended over deprecated CRA
- React 18 (plain JavaScript, no TypeScript)
- Material UI 5 (styling)
- React Router 6 with HashRouter (GitHub Pages compatible)

---

## Project Structure

```
jsquiz/
 .github/workflows/deploy.yml   # GitHub Actions deployment
 public/
 src/
    components/
       Quiz/
          Quiz.jsx           # Main quiz container
          StartScreen.jsx    # Welcome + instructions
          Question.jsx       # Single question display
          Results.jsx        # Score + review
       common/
           Header.jsx         # App header
    data/
       questions.js           # 10 quiz questions
    hooks/
       useQuiz.js             # Quiz state management
    theme/
       theme.js               # MUI theme (JS yellow colors)
    App.jsx                    # Routes configuration
    main.jsx                   # Entry point with providers
 index.html
 package.json
 vite.config.js                 # base: '/jsquiz/' for GH Pages
 README.md
```

---

## Implementation Steps

### 1. Initialize Project
```bash
npm create vite@latest . -- --template react
npm install @mui/material @emotion/react @emotion/styled @mui/icons-material react-router-dom
```

### 2. Configure Vite for GitHub Pages
**vite.config.js:**
```javascript
import { defineConfig } from 'vite';
import react from '@vitejs/plugin-react';

export default defineConfig({
  plugins: [react()],
  base: '/jsquiz/',  // Critical for GH Pages subdirectory
});
```

### 3. Set Up HashRouter
**src/main.jsx:**
```javascript
import { HashRouter } from 'react-router-dom';
// URLs will be: godmar.github.io/jsquiz/#/quiz
```

### 4. Create Quiz Data Structure
**src/data/questions.js** - 10 intermediate JS questions covering:
1. `typeof null` quirk
2. `var` vs `let` in loops (closures)
3. Promise.all behavior
4. Array reduce
5. Object destructuring with defaults
6. Spread operator (shallow copy)
7. `this` in arrow functions
8. Event loop (setTimeout vs microtasks)
9. Hoisting behavior
10. `==` vs `===` coercion

Each question format:
```javascript
{
  id: 1,
  question: "What is the output?",
  code: `console.log(typeof null);`,
  options: [
    { id: 'a', text: '"null"' },
    { id: 'b', text: '"object"' },
    // ...
  ],
  correctAnswer: 'b',
  explanation: "This is a known JavaScript bug..."
}
```

### 5. Implement Quiz Hook (useQuiz.js)
State management for:
- Current question index
- User answers (object: `{questionId: answerId}`)
- Navigation (next/previous/goTo)
- Score calculation
- Submit and reset

### 6. Build Components
- **StartScreen**: Instructions, feature list, "Start Quiz" button
- **Quiz**: Progress bar, Question component, nav buttons
- **Question**: Code block, radio group for options
- **Results**: Score display, question review with explanations

### 7. Create GitHub Actions Workflow
**.github/workflows/deploy.yml:**
```yaml
name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
on:
  push:
    branches: ['main']
permissions:
  contents: read
  pages: write
  id-token: write
jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: '20'
          cache: 'npm'
      - run: npm ci
      - run: npm run build
      - uses: actions/configure-pages@v4
      - uses: actions/upload-pages-artifact@v3
        with:
          path: './dist'
  deploy:
    environment:
      name: github-pages
      url: ${{ steps.deployment.outputs.page_url }}
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: build
    steps:
      - uses: actions/deploy-pages@v4
        id: deployment
```

---

## Quiz UX Flow

1. **Start Screen** (`/#/`) - Instructions, "Start Quiz" button
2. **Quiz** (`/#/quiz`) - One question at a time, progress bar, prev/next nav
3. **Results** (`/#/results`) - Score, percentage, full review with explanations

---

## Key MUI Components
- `Container`, `Card`, `CardContent` - Layout
- `Typography` - Text styling
- `Button` - Actions
- `RadioGroup`, `Radio`, `FormControlLabel` - Answer selection
- `LinearProgress` - Progress indicator
- `AppBar`, `Toolbar` - Header
- `Box` - Spacing and layout

---

## Repository Setup (Manual Steps)
After pushing code:
1. Go to repo Settings > Pages
2. Under "Build and deployment", select **GitHub Actions** as source
3. Push to `main` branch triggers deployment

---

## Verification
1. Run `npm run dev` - test locally at `localhost:5173/jsquiz/`
2. Test all routes work with HashRouter
3. Push to GitHub, verify Actions workflow runs
4. Check deployed site at `godmar.github.io/jsquiz`

             Write /home/gback/cs3754/jsquiz/vite.config.js

import { defineConfig } from 'vite';
import react from '@vitejs/plugin-react';

export default defineConfig({
  plugins: [react()],
  base: '/jsquiz/',
});

import CssBaseline from '@mui/material/CssBaseline';

import React from 'react';
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom/client';
import { HashRouter } from 'react-router-dom';
import { ThemeProvider } from '@mui/material/styles';
import CssBaseline from '@mui/material/CssBaseline';
import App from './App';
import theme from './theme/theme';

ReactDOM.createRoot(document.getElementById('root')).render(
  <React.StrictMode>
    <HashRouter>
      <ThemeProvider theme={theme}>
        <CssBaseline />
        <App />
      </ThemeProvider>
    </HashRouter>
  </React.StrictMode>
);

const theme = createTheme({
  palette: {

import { createTheme } from '@mui/material/styles';

const theme = createTheme({
  palette: {
    primary: {
      main: '#f7df1e', // JavaScript yellow
      contrastText: '#323330',
    },
    secondary: {
      main: '#323330', // JavaScript dark
    },
    background: {
      default: '#1a1a1a',
      paper: '#2d2d2d',
    },
    text: {
      primary: '#ffffff',
      secondary: '#b0b0b0',
    },
  },
  typography: {
    fontFamily: '"Roboto", "Helvetica", "Arial", sans-serif',
    h4: {
      fontWeight: 700,
    },
    h5: {
      fontWeight: 600,
    },
  },
  components: {
    MuiButton: {
      styleOverrides: {
        root: {
          textTransform: 'none',
          fontWeight: 600,
        },
      },
    },
    MuiCard: {
      styleOverrides: {
        root: {
          borderRadius: 12,
        },
      },
    },
  },
});

export default theme;

import { Routes, Route, Navigate } from 'react-router-dom';
import { Box } from '@mui/material';
import Header from './components/common/Header';
import Quiz from './components/Quiz/Quiz';

import { Routes, Route, Navigate } from 'react-router-dom';
import { Box } from '@mui/material';
import Header from './components/common/Header';
import Quiz from './components/Quiz/Quiz';

function App() {
  return (
    <Box sx={{ minHeight: '100vh', bgcolor: 'background.default' }}>
      <Header />
      <Routes>
        <Route path="/" element={<Quiz />} />
        <Route path="/quiz" element={<Quiz />} />
        <Route path="/results" element={<Quiz />} />
        <Route path="*" element={<Navigate to="/" replace />} />
      </Routes>
    </Box>
  );
}

export default App;
